text: In law and in religion, testimony is a formal statement that something is true. The words "testimony" and "testify" both come from the Latin word testis, which refers to a third-party witness. ==Law== In the law, testimony is a kind of evidence. It comes from a witness who says that something is true. Testimony may be spoken or written. It is usually made by oath or affirmation under penalty of perjury (which is a crime that somebody can be charged with if they give testimony that is not true). ==Religion== Some Christians use the term "to testify" or "to give one's testimony" to mean "to tell the story of how one became a Christian". ==References== Category:Religion Category:Legal terms Category:Sources of knowledge
title: Testimony
